problem: Josh and Mike live 13 miles apart. Yesterday Josh started to ride his bicycle toward Mike's house. A little later Mike started to ride his bicycle toward Josh's house. When they met, Josh had ridden for twice the length of time as Mike and at four-fifths of Mike's rate. How many miles had  Mike ridden when they met?
solution:
Because $\text{(rate)(time)} = \text{(distance)}$, the distance Josh rode was $(4/5)(2) = 8/5$ of the distance that Mike rode.  Let $m$ be the number of miles that Mike had ridden when they met. Then the number of miles between their houses is \[
13 = m + \frac{8}{5}m = \frac{13}{5}m.
\]Thus $m = \boxed{5}$.
model_solution:
Let r be the rate at which Mike rides and t be the time that Mike rides. Then 4/5r is the rate at which Josh rides, and 2t is the time that Josh rides.
Since the distances traveled by Josh and Mike are equal, we can set up the equation: rt = (4/5)r(2t)
Cancel out the r and t terms: 1 = (8/5)t
(8/5)t = 1 → (8/5)t × (5/8) = 1 × (5/8) → t = 5/8
(5/8)t = 5/8 → 5/8 × (5r/8) = 5/8 → (25r/64) = 5/8
(64/25)(25r/64) = (5/8) × (25/25) → r = 5/8 × 25/25 → r = 5/16
Distance = rate × time, so the distance Mike rode is 5/16 × 5/8 × 13
(5/16) × (5/8) = 25/128 → (25/128) × 13 = 78/64 → 78/64 × (64/64) = 78/64 → 78/64 × (16/16) = 78/64 × 16/16 → 1248/1024
(1248/1024) = 312/256
(312/256) × 16/16 = 312/256 × 16/16
steps: Let r be the rate at which Mike rides and t be the time that Mike rides. Then 4/5r is the rate at which Josh rides, and 2t is the time that Josh rides.
Since the distances traveled by Josh and Mike are equal, we can set up the equation: rt = (4/5)r(2t)
Cancel out the r and t terms: 1 = (8/5)t
Distance = rate × time, so the distance Mike rode is 5/16 × 5/8 × 13
full_steps: Let r be the rate at which Mike rides and t be the time that Mike rides. Then 4/5r is the rate at which Josh rides, and 2t is the time that Josh rides.
Since the distances traveled by Josh and Mike are equal, we can set up the equation: rt = (4/5)r(2t)
Cancel out the r and t terms: 1 = (8/5)t
Distance = rate × time, so the distance Mike rode is 5/16 × 5/8 × 13
